Based on the search results, I can provide you with comprehensive information about SillyTavern and its role in LLM character persona management and role-playing AI interfaces.

## What is SillyTavern?

SillyTavern (or ST for short) is a locally installed user interface that allows you to interact with text generation LLMs, image generation engines, and TTS voice models. Beginning in February 2023 as a fork of TavernAI 1.2.8, SillyTavern now has over 200 contributors and 2 years of independent development under its belt, and continues to serve as a leading software for savvy AI hobbyists.

## Core Features

### Character Card System
SillyTavern is built around the concept of "character cards". A character card is a collection of prompts that set the behavior of the LLM and is required to have persistent conversations in SillyTavern. They function similarly to ChatGPT's GPTs or Poe's bots. The content of a character card can be anything: an abstract scenario, an assistant tailored for a specific task, a famous personality or a fictional character.

### Unified Interface for Multiple APIs
SillyTavern provides a single unified interface for many LLM APIs (KoboldAI/CPP, Horde, NovelAI, Ooba, Tabby, OpenAI, OpenRouter, Claude, Mistral and more), a mobile-friendly layout, Visual Novel Mode, Automatic1111 & ComfyUI API image generation integration, TTS, WorldInfo (lorebooks), customizable UI, auto-translate, more prompt options than you'd ever want or need, and endless growth potential via third-party extensions.

### Key Capabilities
User personas: let the AI know a bit about you for greater immersion Â· Built-in RAG support: add documents to your chats for the AI to reference Â· Extensive chat commands subsystem and own scripting engine Â· SillyTavern has extensibility support.

## Installation and Setup

DO NOT INSTALL INTO ANY WINDOWS CONTROLLED FOLDER (Program Files, System32, etc). Browse to or Create a folder that is not controlled or monitored by Windows. (ex: C:\MySpecialFolder) Open a Command Prompt inside that folder by clicking in the 'Address Bar' at the top, typing cmd, and pressing Enter. Once the black box (Command Prompt) pops up, type ONE of the following into it and press Enter: for Release Branch: git clone https://github.com/SillyTavern/SillyTavern -b release

## Development Philosophy

We aim to empower users with as much utility and control over their LLM prompts as possible. The steep learning curve is part of the fun! We do not provide any online or hosted services, nor programmatically track any user data. SillyTavern is a passion project brought to you by a dedicated community of LLM enthusiasts, and will always be free and open sourced.

## Branch System

SillyTavern is being developed using a two-branch system to ensure a smooth experience for all users. release -ðŸŒŸ Recommended for most users. This is the most stable and recommended branch, updated only when major releases are pushed. It's suitable for the majority of users. Typically updated once a month.

## Related Projects

### SillyTavern MultiPlayer (STMP)
SillyTavern MultiPlayer is an LLM chat interface, created by RossAscends, that allows multiple users to chat together with each other and an AI.

### Character Factory
This Python script is designed to help you generate characters for SillyTavern, TavernAI, TextGenerationWebUI and many more, using LLM (Large Language Model) and Stable Diffusion. The script utilizes various deep learning models to create detailed character cards, including names, summaries, personalities, greeting messages, and character avatars.

## Target Audience

SillyTavern is a FREE self-hosted and local LLM frontend. âš ï¸ This tool is for power users only. It requires manual installation, API setup, and knowledge of backend configurations. It is not for general users looking for an easy AI chatbot.

SillyTavern represents a comprehensive solution for advanced users who want complete control over their LLM-based character interactions and role-playing experiences, offering extensive customization options and support for multiple AI backends.

Based on the search results, I found several relevant GitHub repositories and resources about real-time chat systems using WebSocket, SSE (Server-Sent Events), and streaming for LLM interfaces. Here are the key findings:

## GitHub Repositories for Streaming LLM Chat

### 1. **Streaming-LLM-Chat** by mickymultani
Interactive chat application leveraging OpenAI's GPT-4 for real-time conversation simulations. Built with Flask, this project showcases streaming LLM responses in a user-friendly web interface.(no content)Interactive chat interface with real-time response streaming.

### 2. **RealtimeVoiceChat** by KoljaB
This project lets you chat with a Large Language Model (LLM) using just your voice, receiving spoken responses in near real-time. Key features include:
- Real-Time Feedback: See partial transcriptions and AI responses as they happen.
- Low Latency Focus: Optimized architecture using audio chunk streaming.
- Web Interface: Clean and simple UI using Vanilla JS and the Web Audio API.

### 3. **LLMChat** by c0sogi
With the WebSocket, you can establish a real-time, two-way communication channel to interact with the LLM.(no content)The WebSocket will send back chat responses in real-time. This is A full-stack Webui implementation of Large Language model, such as ChatGPT or LLaMA.

### 4. **sse-streaming-llm-response** by rishi-raj-jain
Learn how to build use Server-Sent Events (SSE) to stream LLM responses in Next.js with OpenAI. The project uses:
- Vercel AI SDK â€“ An open source library for building AI-powered user interfaces.
- LangChain - Framework for developing applications powered by language models.

### 5. **langchain-chat-websockets** by pors
LangChain LLM chat with streaming response over websockets

### 6. **web-llm** by mlc-ai
Streaming & Real-Time Interactions: Supports streaming chat completions, allowing real-time output generation which enhances interactive applications like chatbots and virtual assistants.(no content)WebLLM is fully compatible with OpenAI API. That is, you can use the same OpenAI API on any open source models locally, with functionalities including streaming, JSON-mode, function-calling (WIP), etc.

## Technical Insights

### SSE vs WebSocket for LLM Streaming

From the Upstash blog article:
- Streaming involves sending data in small, continuous chunks rather than in one large block. In the context of AI applications, like chatbots or recommendation systems, streaming means sending partial responses to users as soon as they're available, instead of waiting to compile and deliver the entire response at once.

From the SoftwareMill comparison:
- It is a part of HTML 5 specification and similarly to WebSockets utilizes a single long live HTTP connection to send data in "real-time".
- However, I would say that SSE can be faster in terms of a pure number of messages sent per second as it kind of works on fire and forget principle. WebSocket needs to also handle responses coming from the client.

### Implementation Approaches

The Aha.io article discusses Rails implementations:
- SSEs are a simple, yet effective way to push data from a server to a webpage in real time. They're particularly well suited for streaming LLM responses due to their simplicity and wide browser support.
- To see a complete working example of these approaches, check out our sample repository on GitHub. It demonstrates both SSE and Turbo Streams implementations for streaming LLM responses in Rails.

These repositories demonstrate various approaches to implementing real-time chat systems with LLMs, using both WebSocket and SSE for streaming responses, with different frameworks including Flask, Next.js, Rails, and browser-based implementations.

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of MCP (Model Context Protocol) tool calling integration with LLM chat interfaces, particularly for Anthropic's Claude:

## What is Model Context Protocol (MCP)?

The Model Context Protocol (MCP) is an open standard for connecting AI assistants to the systems where data lives, including content repositories, business tools, and development environments. It enables developers to build secure, two-way connections between their data sources and AI-powered tools.(no content)MCP addresses the challenge of LLM isolation by providing a standardized way for LLMs to connect with external data sources and toolsâ€”essentially a "universal remote" for AI apps. Technology writers have dubbed MCP "the USB-C of AI apps".

## Key Components and Architecture

The MCP architecture consists of three main components:

1. **Host Applications**: Applications the user interacts with (e.g., Claude Desktop, an IDE like Cursor, a custom agent). This is the parent application or environment where the AI assistant lives.

2. **MCP Clients**: Live within the Host application and manage the connection to one specific MCP server. Maintain a 1:1 connection.

3. **MCP Servers**: External programs that expose Tools, Resources and Prompts via standard API to the AI model via the client.

## Core Capabilities

MCP servers provide three main types of capabilities:

- **Tools**: Functions (tools) that LLMs can call to perform specific actions, e.g. weather API, basically function calling
- **Resources**: Data sources that LLMs can access, similar to GET endpoints in a REST API. Resources provide data without performing significant computation, no side effects.
- **Prompts**: Pre-defined templates to use tools or resources in the most optimal way. Selected before running inference

## Integration with Claude and Other LLMs

All Claude.ai plans support connecting MCP servers to the Claude Desktop app. Claude for Work customers can begin testing MCP servers locally, connecting Claude to internal systems and datasets.(no content)Connect to remote MCP servers directly from the Messages API without building an MCP client. This feature provides seamless integration with MCP-compatible tools and services.

## Solving the Integration Challenge

MCP addresses the "MÃ—N problem" where M represents different AI applications and N represents different tools/systems. Instead of building MÃ—N different integrations, MCP transforms this into an "M+N problem". Tool creators build N MCP servers (one for each system), while application developers build M MCP clients (one for each AI application).

## Implementation and Ecosystem

Pre-built MCP servers are available for popular enterprise systems like Google Drive, Slack, GitHub, Git, Postgres, and Puppeteer.(no content)The protocol was released with software development kits (SDK) in multiple programming languages, including Python, TypeScript, Java, and C#.(no content)In March 2025, OpenAI officially adopted the MCP, integrating the standard across its products, including the ChatGPT desktop app, OpenAI's Agents SDK, and the Responses API. By adopting MCP, OpenAI joins other organizations such as Block, Replit, and Sourcegraph.

## Developer Resources

Developers can start building and testing MCP connectors today. Developer toolkits for deploying remote production MCP servers that can serve entire Claude for Work organizations will soon be provided.(no content)MCP enables seamless integration between LLM applications and external data sources and tools. Whether you're building an AI-powered IDE, enhancing a chat interface, or creating custom AI workflows, MCP provides a standardized way to connect LLMs with the context they need.

The Model Context Protocol represents a significant advancement in standardizing how AI assistants connect with external tools and data sources, making it easier for developers to build more capable, context-aware AI applications without creating custom integrations for each combination of AI model and external system.

results:
Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of MCP (Model Context Protocol) tool calling integration with LLM chat interfaces, particularly for Anthropic's Claude:

## What is Model Context Protocol (MCP)?

The Model Context Protocol (MCP) is an open standard for connecting AI assistants to the systems where data lives, including content repositories, business tools, and development environments. It enables developers to build secure, two-way connections between their data sources and AI-powered tools.(no content)MCP addresses the challenge of LLM isolation by providing a standardized way for LLMs to connect with external data sources and toolsâ€”essentially a "universal remote" for AI apps. Technology writers have dubbed MCP "the USB-C of AI apps".

## Key Components and Architecture

The MCP architecture consists of three main components:

1. **Host Applications**: Applications the user interacts with (e.g., Claude Desktop, an IDE like Cursor, a custom agent). This is the parent application or environment where the AI assistant lives.

2. **MCP Clients**: Live within the Host application and manage the connection to one specific MCP server. Maintain a 1:1 connection.

3. **MCP Servers**: External programs that expose Tools, Resources and Prompts via standard API to the AI model via the client.

## Core Capabilities

MCP servers provide three main types of capabilities:

- **Tools**: Functions (tools) that LLMs can call to perform specific actions, e.g. weather API, basically function calling
- **Resources**: Data sources that LLMs can access, similar to GET endpoints in a REST API. Resources provide data without performing significant computation, no side effects.
- **Prompts**: Pre-defined templates to use tools or resources in the most optimal way. Selected before running inference

## Integration with Claude and Other LLMs

All Claude.ai plans support connecting MCP servers to the Claude Desktop app. Claude for Work customers can begin testing MCP servers locally, connecting Claude to internal systems and datasets.(no content)Connect to remote MCP servers directly from the Messages API without building an MCP client. This feature provides seamless integration with MCP-compatible tools and services.

## Solving the Integration Challenge

MCP addresses the "MÃ—N problem" where M represents different AI applications and N represents different tools/systems. Instead of building MÃ—N different integrations, MCP transforms this into an "M+N problem". Tool creators build N MCP servers (one for each system), while application developers build M MCP clients (one for each AI application).

## Implementation and Ecosystem

Pre-built MCP servers are available for popular enterprise systems like Google Drive, Slack, GitHub, Git, Postgres, and Puppeteer.(no content)The protocol was released with software development kits (SDK) in multiple programming languages, including Python, TypeScript, Java, and C#.(no content)In March 2025, OpenAI officially adopted the MCP, integrating the standard across its products, including the ChatGPT desktop app, OpenAI's Agents SDK, and the Responses API. By adopting MCP, OpenAI joins other organizations such as Block, Replit, and Sourcegraph.

## Developer Resources

Developers can start building and testing MCP connectors today. Developer toolkits for deploying remote production MCP servers that can serve entire Claude for Work organizations will soon be provided.(no content)MCP enables seamless integration between LLM applications and external data sources and tools. Whether you're building an AI-powered IDE, enhancing a chat interface, or creating custom AI workflows, MCP provides a standardized way to connect LLMs with the context they need.

The Model Context Protocol represents a significant advancement in standardizing how AI assistants connect with external tools and data sources, making it easier for developers to build more capable, context-aware AI applications without creating custom integrations for each combination of AI model and external system.

Based on the search results, I found several relevant options for multi-provider LLM chat interfaces with provider switching capabilities and inference controls:

## Key Multi-Provider LLM Solutions

### 1. **LiteLLM** 
LiteLLM is a Python SDK and Proxy Server (LLM Gateway) that allows you to call 100+ LLM APIs in OpenAI format, supporting providers like Bedrock, Azure, OpenAI, VertexAI, Cohere, Anthropic, Sagemaker, HuggingFace, Replicate, and Groq. 

Key features:
- Simple provider switching with consistent API - you can switch between OpenAI and Anthropic calls by just changing the model parameter
- Includes retry/fallback logic across multiple deployments
- Supports streaming responses
- Maps exceptions across all providers to OpenAI exceptions for consistent error handling

### 2. **Instructor**
Instructor is a Python library that supports OpenAI, Anthropic, Google, Ollama, DeepSeek, and 15+ providers, built on Pydantic with automatic retries, streaming, and type safety.

Notable features:
- Provides a unified `from_provider` API that works the same way across all providers - same interface everywhere
- Automatic retries with detailed error messages
- Works with local models through Ollama, llama-cpp-python, and other local inference frameworks

### 3. **CrewAI**
CrewAI supports different LLM providers including OpenAI, Anthropic, and Google with varying capabilities, pricing, and features.

Inference controls:
- Advanced configuration with parameters like temperature (0.7), timeout, max_tokens (4000), top_p (0.9), frequency_penalty, presence_penalty, response_format, and seed
- Temperature (0.0 to 1.0) controls response randomness

### 4. **Langflow**
Langflow provides model components that generate text using large language models from OpenAI and Anthropic. It supports:
- Ollama integration for local language models with configurable base URL
- OpenRouter component for unified API access to multiple AI models from different providers
- Multiple providers including OpenAI, Anthropic, Cohere, and DeepSeek

### 5. **LangChain**
LangChain allows configurable provider switching between models like ChatAnthropic and ChatOpenAI using ConfigurableField.

For Ollama specifically:
- Temperature control for model creativity (Default: 0.8)
- Repetition penalty settings
- Tail free sampling to reduce impact of less probable tokens

## OpenAI-Compatible Approaches

You can build custom FastAPI servers that are compatible with OpenAI API specs, allowing you to wrap any LLM to mimic the OpenAI API using the base_url parameter. These implementations support streaming for better user experience during slow generation.

## Common Inference Controls

The search results show these inference parameters are commonly supported across providers:
- **Temperature**: Controls randomness/creativity
- **top_p**: Nucleus sampling parameter  
- **max_tokens**: Maximum response length
- **frequency_penalty**: Reduces repetition
- **presence_penalty**: Encourages topic diversity
- **streaming**: For real-time response generation

These solutions enable seamless switching between providers while maintaining consistent APIs and control over inference parameters.

Based on my search results, I found several excellent curated lists of LLM interface and chat UI frameworks on GitHub. Here are the key repositories:

## Main Curated Lists for LLM Interfaces and Chat UI Frameworks:

### 1. **awesome-llm-web-ui** by JShollaj
This repository is dedicated to curating the best LLM Web User Interfaces and listing the most awesome Large Language Model (LLM) Web User Interfaces that facilitate interaction with powerful AI models.(no content)These UIs range from simple chatbots to comprehensive platforms equipped with functionalities like PDF generation, web search, and more.

### 2. **awesome-llm-webapps** by snowfort-ai
This repository helps you jump-start your LLM project by starting from an app, not a framework, and aggregates high-quality, functioning web applications for use cases including Chatbots, Natural Language Interfaces, Assistants, and Question Answering Systems.(no content)The projects span a wide range of complexity, from straightforward API wrappers to production-ready systems.

### 3. **Awesome-LLM** by Hannibal046
This is a curated list of papers about large language models, especially relating to ChatGPT, which also contains frameworks for LLM training, tools to deploy LLM, courses and tutorials about LLM and all publicly available LLM checkpoints and APIs. It includes several UI frameworks:
- LiteChain - Lightweight alternative to LangChain for composing LLMs
- Serge - a chat interface crafted with llama.cpp for running Alpaca models
- Chainlit â€” A Python library for making chatbot interfaces

## Notable LLM Chat UI Frameworks Mentioned:

### Component Libraries:
- **@llamaindex/chat-ui** - A React component library that provides ready-to-use UI elements for building chat interfaces in LLM applications, designed to streamline the development of chat-based user interfaces for AI-powered applications.

### Full Applications:
- **LLMChat.co** - Stands out with its workflow orchestration system and focus on privacy, storing all user data locally in the browser using IndexedDB, ensuring your conversations never leave your device.

- **Lobe Chat** - An open-source, high-performance chatbot framework that supports speech synthesis, multimodal, and extensible Function Call plugin system.

- **LibreChat** - Brings together the future of assistant AIs with the revolutionary technology of OpenAI's ChatGPT.

### Other Related Resources:
- **awesome-llm-apps** by Shubhamsaboo - A curated collection of Awesome LLM apps built with RAG, AI Agents, Multi-agent Teams, MCP, Voice Agents, and more, exploring apps that combine LLMs from OpenAI, Anthropic, Gemini, and open-source alternatives with AI Agents, Agent Teams, MCP & RAG.

- **awesome-llm-agents** by kaushikb11 - A curated list of awesome LLM agents frameworks and agent development tools.

These repositories provide comprehensive collections of tools, frameworks, and applications for building LLM-powered chat interfaces, ranging from low-level component libraries to full-featured applications with various capabilities like local deployment, privacy features, and multi-modal support.

input.prompt: Extract information about Open WebUI architecture, provider support, features, and how it could be integrated into an existing system. Focus on technical details, API endpoints, configuration options, and extensibility.

content.content:
Here's a technical overview of Open WebUI based on the README:

Architecture and Provider Support:
- Supports multiple AI model providers:
  - Ollama
  - OpenAI-compatible APIs
  - Supports integration with LMStudio, GroqCloud, Mistral, OpenRouter

Key Technical Features:
- Built-in inference engine for Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG)
- Native Python function calling tool
- Web search and web browsing capabilities
- Image generation integration
- Progressive Web App (PWA) support
- Role-Based Access Control (RBAC)

Configuration and Extensibility:
- Supports environment variables for configuration
- Offers Pipelines Plugin Framework for custom logic
- Supports offline mode via `HF_HUB_OFFLINE` environment variable
- Multiple installation methods:
  - Python pip
  - Docker
  - Kubernetes (kubectl, kustomize, helm)

Deployment Options:
- Docker images with variants:
  - `:main` (standard)
  - `:cuda` (GPU support)
  - `:ollama` (bundled Ollama support)
  - `:dev` (bleeding-edge features)

Recommended System Requirements:
- Python 3.11
- Docker
- Optional: NVIDIA CUDA container toolkit for GPU acceleration

The project emphasizes user-friendliness, offline capabilities, and extensive customization options for AI interface deployment.

content.content:
Based on the README, here are key technical details about LibreChat's architecture:

Architecture & Integrations:
- Multi-model AI platform supporting numerous providers:
  - "Anthropic (Claude), AWS Bedrock, OpenAI, Azure OpenAI, Google, Vertex AI"
  - Supports custom and OpenAI-compatible endpoints
  - Integrates local and remote AI providers like Ollama, Groq, Mistral AI

Key Technical Features:
- Microservices-based with separate client and API components
- Supports Code Interpreter with "Secure, Sandboxed Execution" across multiple programming languages
- Agents & Tools Integration with:
  - No-code custom assistants
  - Extensible tool attachment
  - Model Context Protocol (MCP) support

Authentication & Multi-User:
- "Multi-User, Secure Authentication with OAuth2, LDAP, & Email Login Support"
- Built-in moderation and token management tools

Extensibility:
- Open-source architecture
- Configurable deployment options (local/cloud)
- Supports proxy and reverse proxy configurations

Real-time & Interaction Features:
- Multimodal interactions (image upload/analysis)
- Speech-to-text and text-to-speech capabilities
- Conversation import/export
- Message search functionality

The project emphasizes flexibility, allowing users to "integrate multiple AI models" while maintaining a ChatGPT-inspired user experience.

input.prompt: Extract details about SillyTavern's character management system, API integrations, extensibility features, and how it handles personas and role-playing scenarios. Focus on the technical architecture and integration possibilities.

content.content:
Here's a technical overview of SillyTavern's architecture based on the README:

Character Management System:
- Character cards are the core interaction mechanism
- Cards contain prompts that define AI behavior and personality
- Can represent "an abstract scenario, an assistant, a famous personality or fictional character"
- Supports creating characters for specific tasks or role-playing scenarios

API Integrations:
- Supports multiple LLM backends including:
  - KoboldAI/CPP
  - Horde
  - NovelAI
  - OpenAI
  - Claude
  - Mistral
  - And many others

Extensibility Features:
- Supports plugins for:
  - Emotional character expressions
  - Auto-summarization
  - UI translation
  - Image generation (Stable Diffusion, DALL-E)
  - Text-to-speech
  - Web search integration

Key Technical Capabilities:
- "World Info" system for storing contextual information
- Group chat functionality
- Customizable UI
- User persona management
- Built-in RAG (Retrieval Augmented Generation) support
- Scripting engine for advanced interactions

The platform is designed to be "a locally installed user interface" that provides maximum flexibility for AI interaction scenarios.

Based on my research, here's a comprehensive report on existing chat interface projects and LLM UI frameworks that could be integrated with your Athena system:

## Top Integration Candidates

### 1. **Open WebUI** (Highly Recommended)
**GitHub**: https://github.com/open-webui/open-webui  
**Key Features**:
- Extensive provider support (Ollama, OpenAI, Claude, Mistral, OpenRouter)
- Built-in RAG inference engine
- Pipelines Plugin Framework for custom logic
- Native Python function calling
- Role-Based Access Control (RBAC)
- Progressive Web App (PWA) support
- Docker/Kubernetes deployment options

**Integration Benefits**:
- Highly extensible through pipelines
- Supports offline operation
- Strong community with 200+ contributors
- Environment variable configuration
- Multiple deployment variants (standard, CUDA, dev)

### 2. **LibreChat** (Enterprise-Ready)
**GitHub**: https://github.com/danny-avila/LibreChat  
**Key Features**:
- Multi-provider support (Anthropic, AWS Bedrock, OpenAI, Azure, Google, Vertex AI)
- Secure authentication (OAuth2, LDAP, email)
- Code Interpreter with sandboxed execution
- Model Context Protocol (MCP) support
- Agents & Tools integration
- Multimodal capabilities

**Integration Benefits**:
- Microservices architecture
- Enterprise security features
- Built-in moderation tools
- Conversation import/export
- Proxy/reverse proxy support

### 3. **SillyTavern** (Character-Focused)
**GitHub**: https://github.com/SillyTavern/SillyTavern  
**Key Features**:
- Advanced character card system
- Extensive LLM provider support (KoboldAI, Horde, NovelAI, OpenAI, Claude)
- Built-in RAG support
- Group chat functionality
- Scripting engine for custom interactions
- WorldInfo (lorebook) system

**Integration Benefits**:
- Sophisticated persona management
- Highly customizable UI
- Local deployment focus
- Plugin ecosystem
- Power user oriented

## Specialized Projects by Category

### Real-Time Chat Systems
1. **Streaming-LLM-Chat** - Flask-based real-time GPT-4 chat with WebSocket streaming
2. **RealtimeVoiceChat** - Voice-enabled real-time LLM interaction with low latency
3. **LLMChat** - Full-stack WebUI with WebSocket real-time communication
4. **langchain-chat-websockets** - LangChain LLM chat with streaming over WebSockets

### Multi-Provider Frameworks
1. **LiteLLM** - Universal LLM gateway supporting 100+ providers with unified OpenAI format
2. **Instructor** - Multi-provider Python library (OpenAI, Anthropic, Google, Ollama) with type safety
3. **Langflow** - Visual workflow builder with multiple provider components

### Component Libraries
1. **@llamaindex/chat-ui** - React component library for LLM chat interfaces
2. **Hugging Face Chat UI** - SvelteKit-based interface for HF models

## MCP Integration Opportunities

The Model Context Protocol provides standardized tool calling integration:
- **Architecture**: Host applications â†” MCP clients â†” MCP servers
- **Capabilities**: Tools (functions), Resources (data), Prompts (templates)
- **Support**: Native in Claude Desktop, expanding to OpenAI and other providers
- **Pre-built servers**: Google Drive, Slack, GitHub, PostgreSQL, Puppeteer

## Integration Recommendations

### For Athena System Integration:

1. **Primary Choice: Open WebUI**
   - Most extensible through pipeline framework
   - Strong community and active development
   - Natural fit for your mixed deployment (local + cloud)
   - Built-in RAG aligns with your knowledge needs

2. **Enterprise Alternative: LibreChat**
   - Better for multi-user environments
   - Stronger authentication and security
   - MCP support for tool integration
   - Microservices architecture fits distributed systems

3. **Specialized Use Case: SillyTavern**
   - Best for advanced persona/character management
   - Excellent for testing different AI personalities
   - Strong local deployment focus
   - Advanced customization capabilities

### Technical Integration Patterns:

1. **API Gateway Approach**: Use LiteLLM as a unified provider interface
2. **Component Integration**: Extract UI components from chosen framework
3. **MCP Bridge**: Implement MCP servers for your existing tools
4. **WebSocket Streaming**: Implement real-time response streaming
5. **Pipeline Extension**: Build custom Open WebUI pipelines for Athena-specific logic

### Next Steps:
1. Deploy Open WebUI locally to test integration patterns
2. Implement MCP servers for your existing camera/PTZ tools
3. Create custom pipelines for your specific workflow needs
4. Evaluate real-time streaming performance for your use cases

I've been using OpenWebUI and LibreChat and one other, and they're okay but idk. As long as our agents run in OTP i think it will be fine.

Does having the tool/MCP between the generation and the output affect it? Same question for things like forced JSON responses.

Research the impact of tools, MCP, and forced JSON responses on LLM performance and capabilities. Specifically investigate:

1. **Tool Use Impact on Intelligence**:
   - Does routing all LLM output through tools reduce reasoning capabilities?
   - How does tool calling affect model performance benchmarks?
   - Are there studies comparing direct text generation vs tool-mediated generation?

2. **Character Portrayal and Roleplay**:
   - How do tools/MCP affect an LLM's ability to maintain character consistency?
   - Does tool calling break immersion in roleplay scenarios?
   - Can models maintain personality through tool-mediated interactions?

3. **Forced JSON Response Impact**:
   - Does constraining output to JSON format reduce model creativity/expressiveness?
   - How do structured outputs affect reasoning quality?
   - Are there performance differences between free-form text vs structured responses?

4. **Architectural Considerations**:
   - Best practices for preserving model capabilities while using tools
   - Hybrid approaches (some direct generation, some tool-mediated)
   - How major providers (OpenAI, Anthropic, etc.) handle this in their implementations

Look for research papers, benchmarks, developer experiences, and technical discussions from LLM researchers and practitioners. Focus on practical implications for chat systems and AI character development.

file.content:
# AshChat - Event Inspector System

Real-time event monitoring and inspection for the Athena ecosystem, built with Phoenix LiveView and Ash Framework.

## Quick Start

**Using the service script (recommended):**
```bash
# From dev-tools directory
./ashchat-service.sh start    # Start the server
./ashchat-service.sh status   # Check if running
./ashchat-service.sh logs     # View server logs
./ashchat-service.sh stop     # Stop the server
```

**Manual start:**
```bash
cd /path/to/ash_chat
mix deps.get
mix phx.server
```

## Access Points

- **Event Inspector**: http://localhost:4000/events (main interface)
- **API Health**: http://localhost:4000/api/events/health
- **API Stats**: http://localhost:4000/api/events/stats
- **Event Ingestion**: `POST http://localhost:4000/webhook/test`

## Quick Test

file.content:
defmodule AshChatWeb.Router do
  use AshChatWeb, :router

  pipeline :browser do
    plug :accepts, ["html"]
    plug :fetch_session
    plug :fetch_live_flash
    plug :put_root_layout, html: {AshChatWeb.Layouts, :root}
    plug :protect_from_forgery
    plug :put_secure_browser_headers
  end

  pipeline :api do
    plug :accepts, ["json"]
  end

  scope "/", AshChatWeb do
    pipe_through :browser

    live "/", EventDashboardLive
    live "/chat", ChatLive
    live "/chat/:chat_id", ChatLive
    live "/events", EventDashboardLive
    live "/system", SystemDashboardLive
  end

  # API routes for event collection
  scope "/api", AshChatWeb do
    pipe_through :api

    post "/events", EventController, :create
    get "/events/health", EventController, :health
    get "/events/stats", EventController, :stats
  end

  # Webhook endpoint for collectors (compatibility with existing collector config)
  scope "/webhook", AshChatWeb do
    pipe_through :api

    post "/test", EventController, :create
  end

  # Enable LiveDashboard and Swoosh mailbox preview in development
  if Application.compile_env(:ash_chat, :dev_routes) do
    # If you want to use the LiveDashboard in production, you should put
    # it behind authentication and allow only admins to access it.
    # If your application does not have an admins-only section yet,
    # you can use Plug.BasicAuth to set up some basic authentication
    # as long as you are also using SSL (which you should anyway).
    import Phoenix.LiveDashboard.Router

content.text:
## Ash Chat Interface Description

We're building a comprehensive AI chat system using the Ash Framework with these key features:

**Core Architecture:**
- Built on Phoenix LiveView for real-time interactions
- Uses Ash Framework for resource management
- OTP supervision for reliability and fault tolerance
- Multi-provider LLM support (Ollama, OpenAI, Anthropic)

**Current Implementation:**
- Basic chat interface with multimodal support (text + images)
- Provider configuration system with Ollama at 10.1.2.200:11434
- Inference configuration module for dynamic parameter control
- Event monitoring system integrated in the same app

**What Makes It Different:**
- Full control over the chat experience (unlike OpenWebUI/LibreChat)
- Native OTP integration for distributed agent management
- Designed specifically for Athena's needs
- Can integrate directly with your existing MCP tools (cameras, PTZ, etc.)

**Next Steps:**
- Complete the LiveView UI with inference controls panel
- Test with your Ollama server
- Build room/client system for multi-agent scenarios
- Add character configuration for different AI personas

The key advantage is we're building exactly what you need, running in OTP, with full control over every aspect of the chat experience.

file.content:
import Config

# config/runtime.exs is executed for all environments, including
# during releases. It is executed after compilation and before the
# system starts, so it is typically used to load production configuration
# and secrets from environment variables or elsewhere. Do not define
# any compile-time configuration in here, as it won't be applied.
# The block below contains prod specific runtime configuration.

# ## Using releases
#
# If you use `mix release`, you need to explicitly enable the server
# by passing the PHX_SERVER=true when you start it:
#
#     PHX_SERVER=true bin/ash_chat start
#
# Alternatively, you can use `mix phx.gen.release` to generate a `bin/server`
# script that automatically sets the env var above.
if System.get_env("PHX_SERVER") do
  config :ash_chat, AshChatWeb.Endpoint, server: true
end

if config_env() == :prod do
  # The secret key base is used to sign/encrypt cookies and other secrets.
  # A default value is used in config/dev.exs and config/test.exs but you
  # want to use a different value for prod and you most likely don't want
  # to check this value into version control, so we use an environment
  # variable instead.
  secret_key_base =
    System.get_env("SECRET_KEY_BASE") ||
      raise """
      environment variable SECRET_KEY_BASE is missing.
      You can generate one by calling: mix phx.gen.secret
      """

  host = System.get_env("PHX_HOST") || "example.com"
  port = String.to_integer(System.get_env("PORT") || "4000")

  config :ash_chat, :dns_cluster_query, System.get_env("DNS_CLUSTER_QUERY")

  config :ash_chat, AshChatWeb.Endpoint,
    url: [host: host, port: 443, scheme: "https"],
    http: [
      # Enable IPv6 and bind on all interfaces.
      # Set it to  {0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 1} for local network only access.
      # See the documentation on https://hexdocs.pm/bandit/Bandit.html#t:options/0
      # for details about using IPv6 vs IPv4 and loopback vs public addresses.
      ip: {0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0},
      port: port
    ],
    secret_key_base: secret_key_base

  # ## SSL Support
  #
  # To get SSL working, you will need to add the `https` key
  # to your endpoint configuration:
  #
  #     config :ash_chat, AshChatWeb.Endpoint,
  #       https: [
  #         ...,
  #         port: 443,
  #         cipher_suite: :strong,
  #         keyfile: System.get_env("SOME_APP_SSL_KEY_PATH"),
  #         certfile: System.get_env("SOME_APP_SSL_CERT_PATH")
  #       ]
  #
  # The `cipher_suite` is set to `:strong` to support only the
  # latest and more secure SSL ciphers. This means old browsers
  # and clients may not be supported. You can set it to
  # `:compatible` for wider support.
  #
  # `:keyfile` and `:certfile` expect an absolute path to the key
  # and cert in disk or a relative path inside priv, for example
  # "priv/ssl/server.key". For all supported SSL configuration
  # options, see https://hexdocs.pm/plug/Plug.SSL.html#configure/1
  #
  # We also recommend setting `force_ssl` in your config/prod.exs,
  # ensuring no data is ever sent via http, always redirecting to https:
  #
  #     config :ash_chat, AshChatWeb.Endpoint,
  #       force_ssl: [hsts: true]
  #
  # Check `Plug.SSL` for all available options in `force_ssl`.

  # ## Configuring the mailer
  #
  # In production you need to configure the mailer to use a different adapter.
  # Also, you may need to configure the Swoosh API client of your choice if you
  # are not using SMTP. Here is an example of the configuration:
  #
  #     config :ash_chat, AshChat.Mailer,
  #       adapter: Swoosh.Adapters.Mailgun,
  #       api_key: System.get_env("MAILGUN_API_KEY"),
  #       domain: System.get_env("MAILGUN_DOMAIN")
  #
  # For this example you need include a HTTP client required by Swoosh API client.
  # Swoosh supports Hackney and Finch out of the box:
  #
  #     config :swoosh, :api_client, Swoosh.ApiClient.Hackney
  #
  # See https://hexdocs.pm/swoosh/Swoosh.html#module-installation for details.
end

#!/bin/bash

# PTZ REST API - Setup Script
# This script sets up the Python virtual environment and installs dependencies

set -e

PROJECT_DIR="$(cd "$(dirname "${BASH_SOURCE[0]}")" && pwd)"
VENV_DIR="$PROJECT_DIR/venv"

echo "=========================================="
echo "PTZ Camera Control REST API - Setup"
echo "=========================================="
echo "Project directory: $PROJECT_DIR"

# Check if Python 3 is available
if ! command -v python3 &> /dev/null; then
    echo "Error: Python 3 is required but not installed."
    echo "Please install Python 3.8 or later."
    exit 1
fi

PYTHON_VERSION=$(python3 --version | cut -d' ' -f2)
echo "Python version: $PYTHON_VERSION"

# Create virtual environment if it doesn't exist
if [ ! -d "$VENV_DIR" ]; then
    echo "Creating Python virtual environment..."
    python3 -m venv "$VENV_DIR"
else
    echo "Virtual environment already exists."
fi

# Activate virtual environment
echo "Activating virtual environment..."
source "$VENV_DIR/bin/activate"

# Upgrade pip
echo "Upgrading pip..."
pip install --upgrade pip

# Install dependencies
echo "Installing Python dependencies..."
pip install -r requirements.txt

# Check if webcam-ptz executable exists and is executable
WEBCAM_PTZ="$PROJECT_DIR/webcam-ptz"
if [ ! -f "$WEBCAM_PTZ" ]; then
    echo "Warning: webcam-ptz executable not found at $WEBCAM_PTZ"
    echo "Please ensure the executable is copied to the project directory."
elif [ ! -x "$WEBCAM_PTZ" ]; then
    echo "Making webcam-ptz executable..."
    chmod +x "$WEBCAM_PTZ"
fi

# Create necessary directories
echo "Creating directories..."
mkdir -p screenshots
mkdir -p logs

# Create environment file template
ENV_FILE="$PROJECT_DIR/.env"
if [ ! -f "$ENV_FILE" ]; then
    echo "Creating environment file template..."
    cat > "$ENV_FILE" << EOF
# PTZ REST API Environment Configuration
# Copy this to .env.production for production settings

# Application settings
FLASK_ENV=development
SECRET_KEY=your-secret-key-here

# Camera settings
WEBCAM_PTZ_EXECUTABLE=./webcam-ptz
CAMERA_DETECTION_TIMEOUT=10
SCREENSHOT_DIRECTORY=./screenshots

# API settings
API_RATE_LIMIT=100 per minute
CORS_ORIGINS=*

# Logging settings
LOG_LEVEL=INFO
LOG_FILE=./logs/ptz-api.log
EOF
    echo "Environment file created at $ENV_FILE"
    echo "Please review and modify the settings as needed."
fi

echo "=========================================="
echo "Setup completed successfully!"
echo "=========================================="
echo
echo "To start the development server:"
echo "  1. Activate the virtual environment: source venv/bin/activate"
echo "  2. Run the application: python run.py"
echo "  3. Open your browser to: http://localhost:5000"
echo
echo "To run tests:"
echo "  pytest tests/"
echo
echo "For production deployment:"
echo "  gunicorn -w 4 -b 0.0.0.0:5000 'src.ptz_rest_api.main:create_app()'"
echo

"""
Application configuration settings.

This module contains configuration classes for different environments
(development, production, testing).
"""

import os
from pathlib import Path


class Config:
    """Base configuration class."""
    
    # Application settings
    SECRET_KEY = os.environ.get('SECRET_KEY') or 'ptz-camera-api-secret-key-change-in-production'
    JSON_SORT_KEYS = False
    JSONIFY_PRETTYPRINT_REGULAR = True
    
    # Camera settings
    WEBCAM_PTZ_EXECUTABLE = os.environ.get('WEBCAM_PTZ_EXECUTABLE') or './webcam-ptz'
    CAMERA_DETECTION_TIMEOUT = int(os.environ.get('CAMERA_DETECTION_TIMEOUT', '10'))
    SCREENSHOT_DIRECTORY = os.environ.get('SCREENSHOT_DIRECTORY') or './screenshots'
    
    # API settings
    API_RATE_LIMIT = os.environ.get('API_RATE_LIMIT') or '100 per minute'
    CORS_ORIGINS = os.environ.get('CORS_ORIGINS', '*').split(',')
    
    # Logging settings
    LOG_LEVEL = os.environ.get('LOG_LEVEL', 'INFO')
    LOG_FILE = os.environ.get('LOG_FILE', 'ptz-api.log')
    
    @staticmethod
    def init_app(app):
        """Initialize application with this configuration."""
        # Ensure screenshot directory exists
        screenshot_dir = Path(Config.SCREENSHOT_DIRECTORY)
        screenshot_dir.mkdir(exist_ok=True)


class DevelopmentConfig(Config):
    """Development configuration."""
    
    DEBUG = True
    LOG_LEVEL = 'DEBUG'
    
    # Development-specific settings
    CAMERA_DETECTION_TIMEOUT = 5  # Shorter timeout for development


class ProductionConfig(Config):
    """Production configuration."""
    
    DEBUG = False
    
    # Production-specific settings
    SECRET_KEY = os.environ.get('SECRET_KEY') or None
    
    @staticmethod
    def init_app(app):
        Config.init_app(app)
        
        # Production-specific initialization
        if not ProductionConfig.SECRET_KEY:
            raise ValueError("SECRET_KEY environment variable must be set in production")


class TestingConfig(Config):
    """Testing configuration."""
    
    TESTING = True
    DEBUG = True
    
    # Testing-specific settings
    SCREENSHOT_DIRECTORY = './test_screenshots'
    WEBCAM_PTZ_EXECUTABLE = './mock_webcam_ptz'  # Use mock for testing


# Configuration mapping
config = {
    'development': DevelopmentConfig,
    'production': ProductionConfig,
    'testing': TestingConfig,
    'default': DevelopmentConfig
}

1	#!/usr/bin/env python3
     2	"""
     3	GitHub integration for agent framework.
     4	"""
     5	import os
     6	from typing import Dict, List, Optional, Any
     7	import logging
     8	import github
     9	from github import Github
    10	from github.Issue import Issue
    11	from github.Repository import Repository
    12	
    13	logger = logging.getLogger('github')
    14	
    15	class GithubIntegration:
    16	    """Handles GitHub API interactions."""
    17	    
    18	    def __init__(
    19	        self, 
    20	        repo_owner: str, 
    21	        repo_name: str, 
    22	        token: str,
    23	        issue_number: Optional[int] = None
    24	    ):
    25	        """Initialize GitHub integration."""
    26	        self.repo_owner = repo_owner
    27	        self.repo_name = repo_name
    28	        self.token = token
    29	        self.issue_number = issue_number
    30	        self.repo = None
    31	        self.issue = None
    32	        
    33	        self._initialize()
    34	    
    35	    def _initialize(self):
    36	        """Initialize GitHub client and fetch repository/issue."""
    37	        try:
    38	            # Initialize GitHub client
    39	            self.client = Github(self.token)
    40	            
    41	            # Get repository
    42	            self.repo = self.client.get_repo(f"{self.repo_owner}/{self.repo_name}")
    43	            
    44	            # Get issue if specified
    45	            if self.issue_number:
    46	                self.issue = self.repo.get_issue(self.issue_number)
    47	                
    48	            logger.info(f"GitHub integration initialized for {self.repo_owner}/{self.repo_name}")
    49	            
    50	        except Exception as e:
    51	            logger.error(f"Failed to initialize GitHub integration: {e}")
    52	            raise
    53	    
    54	    def post_comment(self, message: str) -> bool:
    55	        """Post a comment on the issue."""
    56	        if not self.issue:
    57	            logger.warning("No issue specified, cannot post comment")
    58	            return False
    59	        
    60	        try:
    61	            self.issue.create_comment(message)
    62	            logger.info(f"Posted comment to issue #{self.issue_number}")
    63	            return True
    64	        except Exception as e:
    65	            logger.error(f"Failed to post comment: {e}")
    66	            return False
    67	    
    68	    def update_issue(self, title: Optional[str] = None, body: Optional[str] = None, 
    69	                    state: Optional[str] = None, labels: Optional[List[str]] = None) -> bool:
    70	        """Update issue properties."""
    71	        if not self.issue:
    72	            logger.warning("No issue specified, cannot update")
    73	            return False
    74	        
    75	        try:
    76	            # Update specified fields
    77	            kwargs = {}
    78	            if title:
    79	                kwargs['title'] = title
    80	            if body:
    81	                kwargs['body'] = body
    82	            if state and state in ('open', 'closed'):
    83	                kwargs['state'] = state
    84	            
    85	            if kwargs:
    86	                self.issue.edit(**kwargs)
    87	            
    88	            # Update labels if specified
    89	            if labels:
    90	                self.issue.set_labels(*labels)
    91	                
    92	            logger.info(f"Updated issue #{self.issue_number}")
    93	            return True
    94	            
    95	        except Exception as e:
    96	            logger.error(f"Failed to update issue: {e}")
    97	            return False
    98	    
    99	    def check_issue_labels(self) -> List[str]:
   100	        """Get the current labels on the issue."""
   101	        if not self.issue:
   102	            logger.warning("No issue specified, cannot check labels")
   103	            return []
   104	        
   105	        try:
   106	            return [label.name for label in self.issue.get_labels()]
   107	        except Exception as e:
   108	            logger.error(f"Failed to get issue labels: {e}")
   109	            return []
   110	    
   111	    def add_label(self, label: str) -> bool:
   112	        """Add a label to the issue."""
   113	        if not self.issue:
   114	            logger.warning("No issue specified, cannot add label")
   115	            return False
   116	        
   117	        try:
   118	            current_labels = self.check_issue_labels()
   119	            if label not in current_labels:
   120	                self.issue.add_to_labels(label)
   121	                logger.info(f"Added label '{label}' to issue #{self.issue_number}")
   122	            return True
   123	        except Exception as e:
   124	            logger.error(f"Failed to add label: {e}")
   125	            return False
   126	    
   127	    def remove_label(self, label: str) -> bool:
   128	        """Remove a label from the issue."""
   129	        if not self.issue:
   130	            logger.warning("No issue specified, cannot remove label")
   131	            return False
   132	        
   133	        try:
   134	            current_labels = self.check_issue_labels()
   135	            if label in current_labels:
   136	                self.issue.remove_from_labels(label)
   137	                logger.info(f"Removed label '{label}' from issue #{self.issue_number}")
   138	            return True
   139	        except Exception as e:
   140	            logger.error(f"Failed to remove label: {e}")
   141	            return False

version: '3.8'

services:
  # Core API service - runs on both platforms
  api:
    build:
      context: ./api
      dockerfile: Dockerfile
    ports:
      - "8000:8000"
    volumes:
      - ./data:/app/data
      - ./config:/app/config
    environment:
      - ENVIRONMENT=${ENVIRONMENT:-development}
      - CUDA_AVAILABLE=${CUDA_AVAILABLE:-false}
    depends_on:
      - neo4j
      - sam

  # SAM service - conditional build based on environment
  sam:
    build:
      context: ./sam
      dockerfile: ${CUDA_AVAILABLE:-false}_Dockerfile
      args:
        - CUDA_VERSION=${CUDA_VERSION:-11.7.1}
    volumes:
      - ./data:/app/data
    deploy:
      resources:
        reservations:
          devices:
            - driver: ${GPU_DRIVER:-none}
              count: ${GPU_COUNT:-0}
              capabilities: [${GPU_CAPABILITIES:-""}]
    environment:
      - SAM_MODEL=${SAM_MODEL:-vit_h}
      - WEIGHTS_DIR=/app/weights
      - CUDA_VISIBLE_DEVICES=${CUDA_VISIBLE_DEVICES:-}

  # CLIP service - for embeddings, conditional build based on environment
  clip:
    build:
      context: ./clip
      dockerfile: ${CUDA_AVAILABLE:-false}_Dockerfile
    volumes:
      - ./data:/app/data
    deploy:
      resources:
        reservations:
          devices:
            - driver: ${GPU_DRIVER:-none}
              count: ${GPU_COUNT:-0}
              capabilities: [${GPU_CAPABILITIES:-""}]
    environment:
      - CUDA_VISIBLE_DEVICES=${CUDA_VISIBLE_DEVICES:-}

  # Neo4j - knowledge graph backend (same on both platforms)
  neo4j:
    image: neo4j:latest
    ports:
      - "7474:7474"
      - "7687:7687"
    volumes:
      - neo4j_data:/data
      - neo4j_logs:/logs
      - neo4j_import:/var/lib/neo4j/import
      - neo4j_plugins:/plugins
    environment:
      - NEO4J_AUTH=${NEO4J_AUTH:-neo4j/password}
      - NEO4J_dbms_memory_heap_initial__size=${NEO4J_MEMORY_HEAP:-512M}
      - NEO4J_dbms_memory_heap_max__size=${NEO4J_MEMORY_HEAP_MAX:-2G}

  # Review UI - simple web interface for human review
  review-ui:
    build:
      context: ./review-ui
      dockerfile: Dockerfile
    ports:
      - "3000:3000"
    depends_on:
      - api
    environment:
      - API_URL=http://api:8000

volumes:
  neo4j_data:
  neo4j_logs:
  neo4j_import:
  neo4j_plugins:

file.content:
# Camera configuration for athena-ingest
cameras:
  # Camera identification and basic metadata
  camera_01:
    id: "camera_01"
    name: "Front Door"
    location: "entrance"
    coordinates:
      latitude: 40.7128
      longitude: -74.0060
    
    # Physical camera properties
    hardware:
      model: "Reolink RLC-410"
      resolution: "1920x1080"
      fps: 15
      field_of_view: 80
      night_vision: true
    
    # Integration settings
    detection_source:
      provider: "frigate"  # frigate | motion | webrtc
      endpoint: "http://frigate:5000/api/camera_01"
      stream_url: "rtsp://camera_01:554/stream"
    
    # Processing configuration
    processing:
      enabled: true
      motion_threshold: 0.3
      save_stills: true
      save_clips: true
      retain_days: 30
    
    # Storage paths (relative to event storage)
    storage:
      stills_path: "camera_stills/camera_01"
      clips_path: "camera_clips/camera_01"
      metadata_path: "camera_metadata/camera_01"

  camera_02:
    id: "camera_02"
    name: "Backyard"
    location: "garden"
    coordinates:
      latitude: 40.7129
      longitude: -74.0061
    
    hardware:
      model: "Hikvision DS-2CD2085FWD-I"
      resolution: "3840x2160"
      fps: 10
      field_of_view: 90
      night_vision: true
    
    detection_source:
      provider: "motion"
      endpoint: "http://motion:8080/camera_02"
      stream_url: "rtsp://camera_02:554/stream"
    
    processing:
      enabled: true
      motion_threshold: 0.2
      save_stills: true
      save_clips: false
      retain_days: 7
    
    storage:
      stills_path: "camera_stills/camera_02"
      clips_path: "camera_clips/camera_02"
      metadata_path: "camera_metadata/camera_02"

# Global camera settings
global:
  # Detection providers configuration
  providers:
    frigate:
      base_url: "http://frigate:5000"
      api_key: "${FRIGATE_API_KEY}"
      webhook_endpoint: "/api/events/camera"
    
    motion:
      base_url: "http://motion:8080"
      webhook_endpoint: "/api/events/camera"
    
    webrtc:
      base_url: "http://webrtc:8000"
      webhook_endpoint: "/api/events/camera"
  
  # Storage configuration
  storage:
    base_path: "/data/camera_events"
    cleanup_interval: "24h"
    compression: "gzip"
  
  # Processing defaults
  processing:
    default_retention_days: 14
    thumbnail_size: "320x240"
    thumbnail_quality: 85
    max_clip_duration: 300  # seconds

file.content:
version: '3.8'

services:
  motion-detector:
    build:
      context: .
      dockerfile: Dockerfile.motion
    container_name: motion-rpi-camera
    restart: unless-stopped
    
    # Enable access to USB cameras and other devices
    privileged: true
    
    # Device access for USB cameras
    devices:
      - /dev/video0:/dev/video0
      - /dev/video1:/dev/video1  # Optional second camera
    
    # Environment variables for configuration
    environment:
      - CAMERA_ID=rpi_cam_01              # Unique identifier for this camera
      - MQTT_BROKER=192.168.1.100         # Replace with your MQTT broker IP
      - MQTT_PORT=1883
      - MQTT_USERNAME=                     # Optional MQTT username
      - MQTT_PASSWORD=                     # Optional MQTT password
      - MQTT_TOPIC_PREFIX=motion          # MQTT topic prefix
      - TZ=America/New_York               # Set your timezone
    
    # Port mapping
    ports:
      - "8080:8080"  # Web interface
      - "8081:8081"  # Camera stream
    
    # Volume mounts
    volumes:
      - motion_data:/var/lib/motion       # Motion recordings and images
      - motion_config:/etc/motion         # Configuration files
      - motion_logs:/var/log/motion       # Log files
      - /tmp:/tmp/motion                  # Temporary files
    
    # Network configuration
    networks:
      - motion_network
    
    # Health check
    healthcheck:
      test: ["CMD", "/scripts/healthcheck.sh"]
      interval: 30s
      timeout: 10s
      retries: 3
      start_period: 10s
    
    # Labels for easier management
    labels:
      - "motion.camera.id=rpi_cam_01"
      - "motion.type=security-camera"
      - "motion.location=front-door"      # Customize based on camera location

# Named volumes for persistent data
volumes:
  motion_data:
    driver: local
  motion_config:
    driver: local
  motion_logs:
    driver: local

# Network for motion services
networks:
  motion_network:
    driver: bridge

## Summary of Sensitive Information Found

Based on my scan of the Athena repository, here are the sensitive items that should be removed or sanitized before making the repository public:

### 1. **Hardcoded Credentials**
- **Neo4j credentials** in multiple files:
  - `/Users/j/Code/athena/system/sam-pipeline/env.mac` - `NEO4J_AUTH=neo4j/password`
  - `/Users/j/Code/athena/system/sam-pipeline/env.cuda` - `NEO4J_AUTH=neo4j/password`
  - `/Users/j/Code/athena/dev-tools/mcp_settings.json` - `NEO4J_PASSWORD=athena-knowledge`
  - Docker compose files also reference these credentials

### 2. **Personal Paths**
- Multiple files contain absolute paths with `/Users/j/`:
  - `/Users/j/Code/athena/dev-tools/mcp_settings.json`
  - `/Users/j/Code/athena/system/hardware-controls/daemons/config.json`
  - `/Users/j/Code/athena/system/hardware-controls/webcam-ptz-native/mcp_config.json`
  - `/Users/j/Code/athena/system/ash-ai/mcp_settings.json`

### 3. **Placeholder/Weak Secrets**
- `/Users/j/Code/athena/system/hardware-controls/ptz-rest-api/config/app_config.py` - contains `SECRET_KEY = 'ptz-camera-api-secret-key-change-in-production'`

### 4. **Internal Network Details**
- `/Users/j/Code/athena/system/mcp/docker-compose.motion.yml` - contains internal IP `192.168.1.100`

### 5. **Conversation Logs**
- The `/data/claude-logs/` directory contains numerous conversation logs that may contain sensitive information
- `/docs/physics-of-work/CONVERSATION_LOG_20250607_0251.jsonl` - appears to be a large conversation log

### 6. **Empty Token Placeholders**
- `/Users/j/Code/athena/dev-tools/mcp_settings.json` - has empty `GITHUB_PERSONAL_ACCESS_TOKEN`

### Recommendations:

1. **Replace all hardcoded credentials** with environment variables
2. **Use relative paths** instead of absolute paths with `/Users/j/`
3. **Add `.env` files to .gitignore** (already done)
4. **Remove or archive all conversation logs** in `/data/claude-logs/`
5. **Replace internal IPs** with placeholder values or environment variables
6. **Generate proper secret keys** for production configs
7. **Review and sanitize** the conversation log files (*.jsonl)
8. **Consider adding** to .gitignore:
   - `*.jsonl` (conversation logs)
   - Any test data files
   - Personal configuration files

The .gitignore file is already well-configured with proper exclusions for environment files, logs, and temporary data. The main issues are hardcoded values in configuration files that need to be moved to environment variables.

The .gitignore file is already well-configured with proper exclusions for environment files, logs, and temporary data. The main issues are hardcoded values in configuration files that need to be moved to environment variables.

I'll challenge you to keep the Ash Chat MVP extremely lean. Let me identify what's truly essential versus what's complexity/risk:

## Proposed MVP - Challenge Everything

### What I think is ACTUALLY needed for MVP:
1. **Single chat session** - no rooms, no multi-client
2. **Text-only messages** - drop image support for now
3. **One provider (Ollama)** - no provider switching UI
4. **Fixed model** - just use llama3.2, no model selector
5. **Basic send/receive** - no streaming, just complete responses
6. **No persistence** - messages only in memory during session

### What adds complexity/risk:

**High Complexity:**
- ðŸš« **Streaming responses** - WebSocket complexity, error handling
- ðŸš« **Multi-provider support** - Each provider has different APIs/quirks
- ðŸš« **Room system** - Distributed state, presence tracking, sync issues
- ðŸš« **Character configuration** - UI complexity, state management
- ðŸš« **MCP/tool calling** - Parsing, execution, security concerns

**Medium Complexity:**
- âš ï¸ **Image support** - File uploads, storage, multimodal APIs
- âš ï¸ **Inference controls UI** - Lots of form inputs, validation
- âš ï¸ **Chat persistence** - Database schema, migrations
- âš ï¸ **Context management** - Token counting, truncation logic

**Potentially Expensive:**
- ðŸ’° **RAG/semantic search** - Vector storage, embeddings API calls
- ðŸ’° **Long context windows** - More tokens = more cost
- ðŸ’° **Multiple concurrent chats** - Multiplies API costs

### My Ultra-Lean MVP Proposal:
```elixir
# Just this:
- POST message to Ollama
- Show response
- That's it
```

**Questions to challenge scope:**
1. Do you NEED provider switching day 1, or can you just use Ollama?
2. Do you NEED streaming, or can responses just appear when complete?
3. Do you NEED multiple chats, or can users just refresh for new chat?
4. Do you NEED inference controls, or can you hardcode reasonable defaults?
5. Do you NEED persistence, or is session-only memory OK for MVP?

What's the absolute minimum to validate your core hypothesis?

message.content:
1. Ollama OK
2. Seems important
3. Yes, need at least CRUD for chatsa nad CRUD for characters/contexts
4. hardcode reasonable is fine, or even omit to start and we'll go from there.
5. say more about what you want to persist?

content.text:
Good pushback! Let me clarify on persistence and adjust the MVP:

## Persistence Question

By "persistence" I meant:
- **Chat history** - Do messages need to survive server restarts?
- **Character/context definitions** - Should these be in database or config files?
- **User sessions** - Any auth/user tracking?

Since you want CRUD for chats and characters, we need real persistence.

## Revised MVP with Your Requirements

### Core Features:
1. **Ollama-only** âœ“
2. **Streaming responses** (you're right, this IS important for UX)
3. **Chat CRUD**:
   - Create new chat
   - List chats
   - Load chat history
   - Delete chat
4. **Character/Context CRUD**:
   - Create character (name + system prompt)
   - List characters
   - Select character for chat
   - Delete character

### Technical Approach:
- Use Ash resources with Postgres (not ETS) for persistence
- Phoenix Channels for streaming
- Simple character = just name + system prompt for now

### What I'd Still Cut:
- âŒ Rooms/multi-client (just 1 user for now)
- âŒ Import/export
- âŒ Character avatars/images
- âŒ Advanced context management (just append messages)
- âŒ Token counting
- âŒ Search within chats

### Streaming Complexity:
Streaming adds real complexity:
- Error handling mid-stream
- Reconnection logic
- Partial message state
- UI updates during streaming

**Alternative**: Start with complete responses, add streaming as enhancement?

Is streaming a hard requirement for MVP, or could we validate the CRUD/character system first?

defmodule AshChatWeb.ChatLive do use AshChatWeb, :live_view alias AshChat.AI.ChatAgent alias AshChat.AI.InferenceConfig alias AshChat.Resources.Chat @impl true def mount(_params, _session, socket) do # Create a new chat session chat = ChatAgent.create_chat() socket = socket |> assign(:chat, chat) |> assign(:messages, []) |> assign(:current_message, "") |> assign(:image_url, "") |> assign(:processing, false) |> assign(:page_title, "Multimodal Chat") |> assign(:inference_config, InferenceConfig.default_config()) |> assign(:providers, InferenceConfig.get_providers()) |> assign(:show_controls, false) # Subscribe to chat updates if connected?(socket) do Phoenix.PubSub.subscribe(AshChat.PubSub, "chat:#{chat.id}") end {:ok, socket} end @impl true def handle_params(%{"chat_id" => chat_id}, _url, socket) do case Chat.read(chat_id) do {:ok, chat} -> messages = ChatAgent.get_chat_messages(chat_id) socket = socket |> assign(:chat, chat) |> assign(:messages, messages) {:noreply, socket} {:error, _} -> {:noreply, redirect(socket, to: ~p"/chat")} end end def handle_params(_params, _url, socket) do {:noreply, socket} end @impl true def handle_event("send_message", %{"message" => %{"content" => content}}, socket) do if String.trim(content) != "" do socket = assign(socket, :processing, true) # Send the message asynchronously Task.start(fn -> case ChatAgent.process_multimodal_message(socket.assigns.chat.id, content, nil, socket.assigns.inference_config) do {:ok, _ai_message} -> # Broadcast update to all connected clients Phoenix.PubSub.broadcast( AshChat.PubSub, "chat:#{socket.assigns.chat.id}", {:message_processed} ) {:error, error} -> Phoenix.PubSub.broadcast( AshChat.PubSub, "chat:#{socket.assigns.chat.id}", {:error, error} ) end end) socket = socket |> assign(:current_message, "") |> update_messages() {:noreply, socket} else {:noreply, socket} end end def handle_event("send_image_message", %{"message" => %{"content" => content, "image_url" => image_url}}, socket) do if String.trim(image_url) != "" do socket = assign(socket, :processing, true) # Send the image message asynchronously Task.start(fn -> case ChatAgent.process_multimodal_message(socket.assigns.chat.id, content, image_url, socket.assigns.inference_config) do {:ok, _ai_message} -> Phoenix.PubSub.broadcast( AshChat.PubSub, "chat:#{socket.assigns.chat.id}", {:message_processed} ) {:error, error} -> Phoenix.PubSub.broadcast( AshChat.PubSub, "chat:#{socket.assigns.chat.id}", {:error, error} ) end end) socket = socket |> assign(:current_message, "") |> assign(:image_url, "") |> update_messages() {:noreply, socket} else {:noreply, socket} end end def handle_event("validate_message", %{"message" => %{"content" => content}}, socket) do {:noreply, assign(socket, :current_message, content)} end def handle_event("validate_image", %{"message" => %{"image_url" => image_url}}, socket) do {:noreply, assign(socket, :image_url, image_url)} end def handle_event("toggle_controls", _params, socket) do {:noreply, assign(socket, :show_controls, !socket.assigns.show_controls)} end def handle_event("update_provider", %{"provider" => provider}, socket) do config = %{socket.assigns.inference_config | provider: provider} models = InferenceConfig.get_available_models(provider) updated_config = if length(models) > 0, do: %{config | model: List.first(models)}, else: config {:noreply, assign(socket, :inference_config, updated_config)} end def handle_event("update_model", %{"model" => model}, socket) do config = %{socket.assigns.inference_config | model: model} {:noreply, assign(socket, :inference_config, config)} end def handle_event("update_inference_config", %{"config" => params}, socket) do updated_config = Map.merge(socket.assigns.inference_config, %{ temperature: String.to_float(params["temperature"] || "0.7"), top_p: String.to_float(params["top_p"] || "0.9"), max_tokens: validated_config = InferenceConfig.validate_config(updated_config) {:noreply, assign(socket, :inference_config, validated_config)} end @impl true def handle_info({:message_processed}, socket) do socket = socket |> assign(:processing, false) |> update_messages() {:noreply, socket} end def handle_info({:error, error}, socket) do socket = socket |> assign(:processing, false) |> put_flash(:error, def handle_event("send_message", %{"message" => %{"content" => content}}, socket) do
    if String.trim(content) != "" do
      socket = assign(socket, :processing, true)
      
      # Send the message asynchronously
      Task.start(fn ->
        case ChatAgent.process_multimodal_message(socket.assigns.chat.id, content, nil, socket.assigns.inference_config) do
          {:ok, _ai_message} ->
            # Broadcast update to all connected clients
            Phoenix.PubSub.broadcast(
              AshChat.PubSub, 
              "chat:#{socket.assigns.chat.id}", 
              {:message_processed}
            )
          
          {:error, error} ->
            Phoenix.PubSub.broadcast(
              AshChat.PubSub, 
              "chat:#{socket.assigns.chat.id}", 
              {:error, error}
            )
        end
      end)

      socket = 
        socket
        |> assign(:current_message, "")
        |> update_messages()

      {:noreply, socket}
    else
      {:noreply, socket}
    end
  end

def handle_event("send_message", %{"message" => %{"content" => content}}, socket) do
    if String.trim(content) != "" do
      socket = assign(socket, :processing, true)
      
      # Simple Ollama config with system prompt
      config = %{
        provider: "ollama",
        model: "llama3.2",
        temperature: 0.7,
        system_prompt: socket.assigns.system_prompt
      }
      
      # Send the message asynchronously
      Task.start(fn ->
        case ChatAgent.process_message_with_system_prompt(
          socket.assigns.chat.id, 
          content, 
          config
        ) do
          {:ok, _ai_message} ->
            Phoenix.PubSub.broadcast(
              AshChat.PubSub, 
              "chat:#{socket.assigns.chat.id}", 
              {:message_processed}
            )
          
          {:error, error} ->
            Phoenix.PubSub.broadcast(
              AshChat.PubSub, 
              "chat:#{socket.assigns.chat.id}", 
              {:error, error}
            )
        end
      end)

      socket = 
        socket
        |> assign(:current_message, "")
        |> update_messages()

      {:noreply, socket}
    else
      {:noreply, socket}
    end
  end

def process_message_with_system_prompt(chat_id, message_content, config \\ %{}) do
    # Create user message
    _user_message = send_text_message(chat_id, message_content, :user)
    
    # Get conversation history
    messages = get_chat_messages(chat_id)
    
    # Add system prompt as first message if provided
    langchain_messages = if config[:system_prompt] do
      [%Message{role: :system, content: config.system_prompt} | convert_to_langchain_messages(messages)]
    else
      convert_to_langchain_messages(messages)
    end
    
    # Process with AI
    agent = create_ai_agent(config)
    
    try do
      case LLMChain.run(agent, langchain_messages) do
        {:ok, response} ->
          content = case response do
            %{content: content} when is_binary(content) -> content
            _ -> "AI response processed"
          end
          
          # Create AI response message
          ai_message = send_text_message(chat_id, content, :assistant)
          
          {:ok, ai_message}
        
        {:error, error} ->
          {:error, "AI processing failed: #{inspect(error)}"}
      end
    rescue
      error ->
        {:error, "AI processing failed: #{inspect(error)}"}
    end
  end

  def process_multimodal_message(chat_id, message_content, image_url \\ nil, inference_config \\ %{}) do

defmodule AshChat.AI.ChatAgent do
  @moduledoc """
  AI Chat Agent for multi-modal conversations using AshAI
  """

  alias LangChain.Chains.LLMChain
  alias LangChain.ChatModels.ChatOpenAI
  alias LangChain.Messages.Message
  alias AshChat.Resources.{Chat, Message}
  alias AshChat.Tools
  alias AshChat.AI.InferenceConfig

  def create_chat() do
    Chat.create!(%{title: "New Multimodal Chat"})
  end

  def send_text_message(chat_id, content, role \\ :user) do
    Message.create_text_message!(%{
      chat_id: chat_id,
      content: content,
      role: role
    })
  end

  def send_image_message(chat_id, content, image_url, role \\ :user) do
    # For now, we'll store the image URL. Later we can add image processing
    Message.create_image_message!(%{
      chat_id: chat_id,
      content: content,
      image_url: image_url,
      role: role
    })
  end

  def get_chat_messages(chat_id) do
    Message.for_chat!(chat_id: chat_id)
  end

  def create_ai_agent(inference_config \\ %{}) do
    config = InferenceConfig.validate_config(inference_config)
    chat_model = InferenceConfig.create_chat_model(config)
    
    %{
      llm: chat_model,
      tools: Tools.list(),  # Enable AI tool calling
      verbose: true
    }
    |> LLMChain.new!()
  end

  def process_multimodal_message(chat_id, message_content, image_url \\ nil, inference_config \\ %{}) do
    # Create user message
    _user_message = if image_url do
      send_image_message(chat_id, message_content, image_url, :user)
    else
      send_text_message(chat_id, message_content, :user)
    end

    # Get conversation history
    messages = get_chat_messages(chat_id)
    
    # TODO: Get relevant context using semantic search when vectorization is enabled
    # context_messages = if length(messages) > 5 do
    #   case Message.semantic_search(%{
    #     query: message_content,
    #     limit: 3,
    #     threshold: 0.8
    #   }) do
    #     {:ok, relevant} -> relevant
    #     {:error, _} -> []
    #   end
    # else
    #   []
    # end
    context_messages = []
    
    # Combine recent messages with relevant context
    all_messages = (context_messages ++ messages) |> Enum.uniq_by(& &1.id)
    
    # Convert to LangChain format
    langchain_messages = convert_to_langchain_messages(all_messages)
    
    # Process with AI
    agent = create_ai_agent(inference_config)
    
    try do
      # Run with tool support (streaming handled separately)
      case LLMChain.run(agent, langchain_messages) do
        {:ok, response} ->
          # Handle potential tool calls in response
          content = case response do
            %{content: content} when is_binary(content) -> content
            %{tool_calls: tool_calls} when is_list(tool_calls) ->
              # Handle tool call responses
              tool_results = Enum.map(tool_calls, &format_tool_result/1)
              "Tool calls executed:\n" <> Enum.join(tool_results, "\n")
            _ -> "AI response processed"
          end
          
          # Create AI response message
          ai_message = send_text_message(chat_id, content, :assistant)
          
          {:ok, ai_message}
        
        {:error, error} ->
          {:error, "AI processing failed: #{inspect(error)}"}
      end
    rescue
      error ->
        {:error, "AI processing failed: #{inspect(error)}"}
    end
  end

  defp convert_to_langchain_messages(ash_messages) do
    Enum.map(ash_messages, fn msg ->
      case msg.message_type do
        :text ->
          %Message{
            role: msg.role,
            content: msg.content
          }
        
        :image ->
          # For multimodal messages with images
          content = if msg.image_url do
            [
              %{type: "text", text: msg.content},
              %{type: "image_url", image_url: %{url: msg.image_url}}
            ]
          else
            msg.content
          end
          
          %Message{
            role: msg.role,
            content: content
          }
        
        _ ->
          %Message{
            role: msg.role,
            content: msg.content
          }
      end
    end)
  end

  defp format_tool_result(%{name: name, result: result}) do
    "#{name}: #{result}"
  end

  defp format_tool_result(%{function: %{name: name}, result: result}) do
    "#{name}: #{result}"
  end

  defp format_tool_result(tool_call) do
    "Tool executed: #{inspect(tool_call)}"
  end
end

def handle_event("send_image_message", %{"message" => %{"content" => content, "image_url" => image_url}}, socket) do
    if String.trim(image_url) != "" do
      socket = assign(socket, :processing, true)
      
      # Send the image message asynchronously
      Task.start(fn ->
        case ChatAgent.process_multimodal_message(socket.assigns.chat.id, content, image_url, socket.assigns.inference_config) do
          {:ok, _ai_message} ->
            Phoenix.PubSub.broadcast(
              AshChat.PubSub, 
              "chat:#{socket.assigns.chat.id}", 
              {:message_processed}
            )
          
          {:error, error} ->
            Phoenix.PubSub.broadcast(
              AshChat.PubSub, 
              "chat:#{socket.assigns.chat.id}", 
              {:error, error}
            )
        end
      end)

      socket = 
        socket
        |> assign(:current_message, "")
        |> assign(:image_url, "")
        |> update_messages()

      {:noreply, socket}
    else
      {:noreply, socket}
    end
  end
